subhead: Barring an eleventh-hour deal, the reinstatement of sanctions – triggered by Britain, France and Germany – will once again freeze Iranian assets abroad, halt arms deals with Tehran and penalize any development of Iran's ballistic missile program, among other measures.

title: Kimmel boycott ends as Sinclair and Nexstar put the late-night comedian back on the air
subhead: 'Jimmy Kimmel Live!' was temporarily pulled off the air after comments the comedian made in the wake of the murder of right-wing activist Charlie Kirk. After a public outcry over freedom of speech, ABC reversed course on Tuesday. Sinclair and Nexstar, which each own dozens of ABC-affiliated channels, followed suit on Friday.

title: 'To frame Kirk's death as escalation misses the truth. The real threat is normalization'
subhead: British geographer Clionadh Raleigh examines the consequences of the assassination of the conservative influencer. By dismissing the fact that the man charged with this murder is a 'lone wolf' and accusing the left, the Trump administration is paving the way for more violence, she says.

subhead: Nicolas Sarkozy will become the first former president of the French Republic to sleep behind bars after being convicted of criminal conspiracy, in the case of alleged Libyan financing of his 2007 presidential campaign.

title: Sarkozy's other legal battlefield: Qatar
subhead: Although not currently facing charges, the former French president is implicated in two judicial investigations: one concerning the controversial awarding of the 2022 FIFA World Cup to Qatar, and another linked to French businessman Arnaud Lagardère.

title: Alexus Grynkewich, top NATO commander in Europe: 'Russia has always tried to maneuver for advantage over the alliance'
subhead: As the repercussions of the war in Ukraine increasingly impact Europe, NATO's new supreme allied commander Europe explains the measures aimed at countering any actions that target NATO member states.
